awd_abstract_narration:
Automation is affecting many sectors of the world economy, from transportation to manufacturing.  Such automation can result in loss of lower skill jobs, as well as create opportunities for new, often higher skill jobs.  Some studies suggest that more than 60% of the jobs in the inland region of southern California are automatable and, therefore at risk.  To buffer this potential job loss, the Riverside Community College District/Norco Campus will develop a work-based learning program in the field of advanced manufacturing automation.  This program will include accredited apprenticeships, coursework, certificates, and degree pathways. Apprenticeships are a potential solution for employers seeking to build their workforce and for students pursuing greater career opportunities. Norco College will establish and expand partnerships with employers and develop curriculum related to work-based learning and apprenticeship. This apprenticeship project aims to provide students with a foundation of technical knowledge in automation and manufacturing, as well as hands-on experiences in the industry.

The project aims to respond to the need for highly-qualified technicians in automation by: (1) developing a comprehensive apprenticeship program to train technicians to fill emerging automation-related technical occupations; (2) building partnerships with industry to ensure industry needs are being met, and to increase employer engagement; (3) implementing new strategies to support student recruitment, retention, and completion targeting underrepresented student populations (including women); (4) supporting existing apprenticeship programs; and (5) encouraging the implementation of accredited apprenticeship programs nationwide.  These efforts will be coordinated with the state and federal apprenticeship agencies, the local Workforce Development Boards, and the California Community College system, with the goal of developing a systematic approach to apprenticeship opportunities in the region.  The project has the potential to draw new talent into industries that are struggling to overcome the skills-gap, while increasing participation of populations underrepresented in the automation manufacturing industries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The significant results of the program have been much better than anticipated although more than fifty percent of the grant was operated under the restrictions of the COVID 19 Pandemic. Overall, the program achieved very significant and important milestones since its inception. Some examples of the achievements include the following:

-Created two apprenticeship certificates for apprentices to complete, Tech I and Tech II. These are additional certificates apprentices obtain as they finish their program at the college.  During the grant period, 44 students completed college certificates alongside registered apprenticeship completeion certificates.

-Created the APP-450 course for apprentices to support apprentices’ work experience needs, work with a faculty mentor and receive guidance for up to two years in the program.

-Created a monthly virtual outreach and now a weekly info session where prospective apprentices come to learn the unique aspects and benefits of the apprenticeship program

-Increased the number of large partnerships in the region with very important organizations that play a key role in the success of the program like the Riverside County America's Job Center, Target,  California Employment Development Department (EDD), Inland Empire United Way/211, City of Corona Economic Development Department and many others

-Developed a new apprentice file management and maintenance system to track progress and to achieve a higher level of compliance.

-Developed a new system to enroll apprentices into the program and provides the various apprenticeship pathways to prospective apprentices.

-Developed new guidelines to track the various procedures and systems required of the program. The guidelines can be modified as needed to meet new changes to the program.

 

In addition to these programmatic achievements, the NCAP project also piloted a college-coordinated registered apprenticeship model that is now being used regionally across twelve partnering community colleges and five industry sectors.  NCAP's work was instrumental in establishing a framework for colleges in California to serve apprentice students and to provide regional employers a streamlined process for plugging into the registered apprenticeship system.  The model has effectively served large businesses while also establishing a system of aggregating smaller businesses into cluster-based apprenticeship committees.


Last Modified: 10/26/2022
Modified by: Charles Henkels
